ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Neuron functions
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Mode is an interesting suggestion. I can see that it might be useful, but how do you calculate it when you have a set of floating point numbers? I guess

mike woodhouse wrote:

>On Mon, 01 Nov 2004 14:12:07 +0000, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>[Collection Functions] - Some of these taken from an ealier post by Ian B.
>>-----------------------
>>Add
>>Multiply (can also perform division by using input<1.0)
>>Logical AND
>>Logical OR
>>Variance
>>Min
>>Max
>>Sum squares
>>    
>>
>
>Mean? Median? Mode?
>  
>
Mode is an interesting suggestion. I can see that it might be useful, 
but how do you calculate it when you have a set of floating point 
numbers? I guess you could just define a range, say ten ranges of width 
0.1, or 5 of 0.2.

>>[Activation functions]
>>----------------------
>>Linear
>>Inverse Linear
>>Sigmoid
>>Step
>>    
>>
>
>Some sort of odd-numbered root (cube? fifth?)
>  
>
Yeh I think the flat region in the center of these functions could be 
useful.

>
>
>Offered without prejudice, I don't know how many extra dimensions
>you'd be adding, or how much value they'd add, although I'm immensely
>curious to see...
>  
>
My intention is to try to keep the list of functions as minimal as 
possible so as to keep the number of additional dimensions to a minimum. 
For instance some of the functions could themselves be parameterised, 
but I am avoiding this for now - in the past I have experimented with a 
parameterised sigmoid where the slope's gradient and center point could 
be searched and also the sigmoid could be flipped around.

So if there is a function that could actually be described with a simple 
structure incorporating the other functions then that fn would be a 
candidate for being dropped. At the same time I want to cover as much 
functionality as possible. It's a balance, and my current viewpoint is 
that using just a sigmoid is possibly at the extreme, non-optimal, end 
of that balance.
